thread.title_full: Tony Abbott’s 2015 Budget sees massive drop in voters worried about their finances

author: John Rolfe Cost of Living Editor
title: Tony Abbott’s 2015 Budget sees massive drop in voters worried about their finances
text:
OF ALL the analysis to emerge since the Abbott Government’s second Budget, this is perhaps the most telling politically and economically — new research showing a huge drop in the number of households left feeling worse off.
As the Coalition attempts to belt-tighten without being belted by voters, a national survey reveals a 38 percentage point plunge in the proportion of people concerned they will be in the red as a result of the 2015 Budget, when compared to reactions to the 2014 fiscal blueprint.

ANGER: Hockey blasted for ‘crazy’ rant
Joe Hockey ... the cost of living has re-emerged as the number one worry for many Australians, a survey has revealed. Source: News Corp Australia
The ME Bank Household Financial Comfort Report, based on a poll of 1500 Australians, finds 29 per cent expect the 2015 Budget will have a negative effect on their financial situation over the 12 months, down from 67 per cent after last year’s budget. The decline in dismay is greatest for couples with children. Among respondents with older kids there has been a 42 percentage point fall in those concerned and a 39 point reduction for those with young ones.
Analysed by worker group, the self-employed recorded the biggest turnaround, with negativity falling from 62 per cent after Mr Hockey’s first Budget to 21 per cent now.
Concern is lowest in Queensland, at 22 per cent, followed by Victoria at 27 per cent then NSW on 28 per cent.
Puff stuff ... Mathias Cormann and Joe Hockey may have cracked open the cigars after the 2014 budget, but they really should have saved them for the 2015 version. Picture: Simon Cullen, Channel 9 Source: Channel 9
The ME Bank research supports findings in the latest NAB consumer anxiety index, which show government policy was no longer the top concern.
“Post the budget, clearly that kicked down,” said NAB’s head of behavioural and industry economics Dean Pearson.
The cost of living re-emerged as the number one worry.
“The budget didn’t seem to do anything much on that,” Mr Pearson said. While there were signs of increased spending on eating out and entertainment, “you still are seeing that people are focusing very much on essentials — paying off debts, medical expenses and utility bills”.
Fears about job security are on the rise, according to the NAB index, published late last month.
ME economist Jeff Oughton, formerly of the Reserve Bank, said the labour market improvement was needed in order to lift consumer confidence and household spending: “More jobs, more hours and more pay.”
While wage growth is at historic lows, there are signs that unemployment won’t go any higher.
June’s official jobless figures will be published on Thursday, with expectations that 10,000 positions will have been added to the economy, keeping the unemployment rate at 6 per cent.
Since the Budget, the Coalition has narrowed Labor’s two-party-preferred lead from 10 points to six, 53-47.
Originally published as Voters more positive about finances
